Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 12:13AM BShoemaker wrote: Hello ladies...I'm going to be part of the June team as well.  I was diagnosed May 19 and have been thrown into a whirlwind during this process.  I met with my Oncologist for the first time last week and was told I would be starting Chemo the following week.  This is before surgery etc..  They want to shrink my more aggressive tumor which is a grade 3.  My other breast has a smaller grade 1 tumor.  I have had numerous tests pretty much every day...MUGA Scan, BRCA test etc...on Monday I get my PET scan and Tuesday the Picc Line placement then Thursday will be my first chemo appt.  I have 4 cycles of chemo before surgery.  It would be great if we could keep in touch during this process and help to keep our spirits up!  I have not met with my surgeon yet, but have been advised the team of doctors that were studying my case have recommended a bilateral mastectomy.  That's a lot to swallow, but if that is what it takes to survive this, then by all means help yourself to both!  I am struggling a bit with the going bald issue since I will be working through my chemo.  I've never been a hat person, but am going to do some shopping tomorrow & see what I find. Best of luck to everyone and keep me posted of your experiences! Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 04:25PM BShoemaker wrote: Engtchr - I had a MUGA scan and it was pretty simple.  They put an IV in you and take some blood.  They keep the IV in your arm taped in place while they mix medicine with your blood for about 25 minutes.  Then they come back in & put the blood/medicine mix back in your arm & remove the IV.  Then you go to take the scan which is very easy.  You lay on a table while they view a screen with your heart image on it to see how the blood is pumping/flowing etc...  The scanner comes over your heart area where it takes a picture for 10 minutes and you just hang out, lay there & wait.  It takes 3 10 minute pictures of different angles of your heart, then your done!  It was really one of the easiest tests of all that I've had.  Unfortunately I hate needles so I wasn't thrilled about that part, but out of all of my tests is was very simple and I was relaxed the entire time they did the scan.  They played a music CD for me...Sade.  ha ha ha.... Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 04:56PM BShoemaker wrote: Hello ladies, Okay...I'm so happy right now I could scream out loud!  The Chemo went better than I could ever ask for.  My nurse was so sweet and just took great care of me.  She walked me through the whole thing & answered all our questions.  She practically jumped for joy when I told her I had a Picc Line because it makes it SO much easier for them...no trying to find a vein/needles etc.  I may have already mentioned that I HATE needles and am now thrilled I got the Picc Line.  It took all the anxiety away from the whole process.  They were very careful about making sure I didn't have any bad reactions to the Chemo meds and I didn't.  My nurse was thrilled and we agreed that everything went so well.  So far I'm doing fantastic.  Just came home & had a little Chicken Noodle soup & crackers.  I don't want to eat anything real heavy just to play it safe.  I will keep you posted for the next few days & let you know how it goes.  I met a really sweet lady next to me that had Ovarian cancer a few years ago, beat it, but now has Lymphoma.  She had such a great attitude though...truly amazing.  I think I was the youngest person there for sure (I'm 39) .  I also drank two quarts of Gatorade during the chemo...lots of liquid and peeing!  :-)  Kind of weird the first time walking to the bathroom with my pole of meds, but it really went well...so happy! I hope everyone can find a way to relax & not have such anxiety over this.  I think if we learn to relax a little it may really help the healing process.  I can't promise I won't be back to a loony when I have my surgery, but at least I've got about 12 weeks to go before I jump that hurdle.  I meet with my surgeon for the first time on Monday, June 8 as well as a f/u with my Oncologist to get the PET/CT scan results.  I'm going to see how I do over the weekend and if I'm feeling up to it, will try to go to a hat shop in Long Beach I found.  Will also keep researching the wigs.  I need to get over it & just get it done! Hugs to you all! Bettin
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 11:29AM BShoemaker wrote: Hi Ladies, it's been a while since I've posted.  I've been feeling fantastic since my 1st Chemo treatment on June 4th.  I only had 2 1/2 days of feeling dizzy and flu like symptoms with a bit of nausea.  Not too bad at all.  Otherwise I feel completely normal as though I don't even have Cancer.  It's weird....not what I expected at all.  Rinna40 - I too have a Picc Line and it is annoying having to wrap it daily when I shower, but I'm all for it if I don't have to get a needle stuck in me every time I see a doctor!  I use saran wrap to cover it and wrap that soft white tape on both ends of the saran wrap to keep it sealed.  Then I bought a "sleeve" from Rite Aide or CVS that is used to keep it covered in the shower for extra protection.  It works great.  The sleeve from the drug store was only about $7.00. Paulingmom - as far as what I did during my first Chemo....My dad, step-mom and husband came with me.  We talked, talked & talked some more!  It really made the time fly by for me even though we were there for 6 hours!  I sat next to a lady that was very sweet and she talked to me about her experience with Chemo as she had treatments 3x a week!    The nurses were also very sweet and chatted with me quite a bit as well explaining every little thing to me and my family as well.  I had an entire bag filled with magazines, ipod, book etc...and never used any of them!   I'm 39 years old, but was so surprised how comforting it was to have my dad there with me.  I felt so protected and safe with him there....it almost felt as though I was going back in time when you need your parents as a child to comfort you.  I would recommend asking to sit in a particular chair if you see someone that looks like they might be friendly or chatty.  They offered me my pick of seats.  Plus my Chemo is right by the ocean (I live in Southern California) and the windows have a full view of the Pacific so the other gal I spoke with said she is sure to pick her chair to get the best view of the beach!   Hope this helps!  Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 11:11PM BShoemaker wrote: Just_Mary - I too have a picc line and have some suggestions for you.  First of all they did not leave my picc line dangling.  How stupid is that?  Of course your afraid it's going to pull out!  My Chemo nurses first put a soft gauze bandage under the port and over it so that it does not sit against your skin, then they put two large clear plastic type bandages over it.  They have some that are completely clear & some that are clear with a light soft covering over the plastic.  They are very comfortable and move easily with your arm.  My picc line is in the same place as yours. Because I was paranoid when I first got home with it, my husband took a long sleeve soft cotton shirt and cut the top of the arm off at the seam and 1/2 way down the arm so I could just slip it up my arm & over the picc line area.  It is very soft and comfy and gave me a sense of comfort that I would not hurt the area.  Even the doctor that did the picc line placement did not leave the port dangling.  He also covered it with a big clear plastic bandage so the entire thing was covered and would stay dry.  I purchased the shower sleeve at Rite Aide or CVS drug store for about $7.00.  I use it every day!  Plus I wrap it with saran wrap for extra safe keeping when showering, then slip the shower sleeve over it. Hope this helps! Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 09:58PM BShoemaker wrote: Pdaw - I have 4 treatments before surgery so I am now halfway through...however, I will have 2 more chemo treatments after surgery as well. :(  Chemo went well today...no issues at all.  I did wake up last night about 4:00am to find my body soaking wet from my head to my lower back.  That was a first!  Very strange!  Do you go into Chemo-pause that early?  Anyone else having these symtoms - please do tell! The funny thing is the Chemo doesn't scare me...the surgery scares the crappola out of me!  I don't like getting my blood taken let alone having someone remove my boobs! zuzzeee - After I got home from work I put on a baseball cap and went grocery shopping without the wig.  I found myself staring at everyone to see if they were staring at me.  I then realized yes, people might look, but then they will just go about their business. My husband said most people never even noticed...and he was right.  At the end of the day who cares?  I wore my baseball cap to Chemo today and I saw a lady getting Chemo herself staring at me..that was strange.  I thought for sure that's one place where people would not stare.  But I thought about it and she still had her hair...I wondered if she was looking at me picturing what she would be facing soon herself.  Who knows.  Then a lady came in & sat next to me for her treatment.  She was completely bald...not a hair in site.  She wore a little purple hat, but it had very little coverage.  She was so comfortable with herself and it inspired me even more.  She spoke about her surgery she had and advised me she was single and doing this all on her own.  She was by herself...people drop her off at Chemo & pick her up.  She then invited me to a group therapy she goes to every Tuesday morning.  I may just go to check it out.  I really felt at that moment how lucky I am to have my husband, father, step-mom and friends so supportive during this time in my life.  My dad came with me to chemo...he has been coming to all my major doctor appts & Chemo treatments and he lives about 4 hours away.  He and I are closer than ever.  He got to see his daughter bald for the first time today.  He has been bald for 1/2 of his life so he cracked a joke that at least mine would grow back, unlike his own.  It was funny and so true!  Just so you know....I am now laughing about the wig incident.  I could still give her a good whack on her head, but will restrain myself.  I have decided I will not be wearing the wig to work though...I will go the baseball cap route...I know I need to feel comfortable and my wig is just not making me comfortable.  :(   I will get through this.  It is what it is and I can handle it.  Laura - I knew you would get a good laugh at the wig story!  I am so proud of you for going bald at work!  If I looked as good as you do with a buzz, I would too.  Unfortunately, mine is so patchy and jacked up...I'm going to keep the baseball cap on I think.  I'm glad your co-workers are enlighted.  That certainly helps.  Hugs all, Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 06:53AM BShoemaker wrote: greytmom - I have a Picc Line instead of a port and it works very well.  No pricks ever for Chemo.  It's a semi-permanent line that is in my left arm.  They keep it covered up with gauze and big plastic bandages.  I hate needles and this prevents me from ever getting pricked for Chemo or blood draws.  They can do both from my Picc Line.  Maybe ask your Onc. about getting one?  The only issue with it is that you do have to cover it up for showers.  I use saran wrap and a shower sleeve for protection.  It has taken away all the anxiety for me which is worth the hassle for me!  Ladies - I am laughing my butt off reading your posts about the little baby hairs now.  That is exactly my problem now!  I find myself obsessed with getting them off of my head!  Then they get all over my pillow, nightgown, etc....  They are driving me nuts too.  Hubby offered to take a razor to my head, but I don't think so!  That scares me!  The clippers were bad enough!  I really like the lint roller idea!  I think I'll go grab one now in fact!  Thanks for the tip! So I just had Chemo #2 on Thursday, June 25.  I have not experienced any nausea at all.  This time around I used EMEND nausea meds and they worked very well for me.  Insurance charged $60.00 for the 3 pills, but I think it's worth it to not feel sick to my stomach etc...   Just a tip for those with bad nausea.  I'm now a firm believer in EMEND.  On Saturday I was extremely sleepy though...I slept most of the day.  I would rather sleep though than feel sick! Bonnid - try drinking gatorade...that might help with the dehydration. As far as the concentration - I could not focus yesterday at all, but today am feeling much better.  I guess that's the Chemo-brain kicking in??? Hugs to you all, Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 08:58PM BShoemaker wrote: Polly, I can't begin to tell you how much I can and am relating to everything about the hair issue!  I was the one that went to work and the damn girl ran her fingers through my wig....remember???  :( Today was my first day back to work after a Chemo treatment last week.  I was so pissed about the wig incident I ended up just wearing a ball cap to work today.  Ok, so I hid in my office all day with the blinds drawn and the door closed most of the way, but I made it through the day.  Only a few people actually saw me.  I noticed they just looked and never said a word or commented.  My boss came in after an hour or so to test the waters.  LOL!  He said he wanted to give me some time to adjust then come in and see how I was doing.  I told him I was hiding in my office, too embarrassed to come out.  He told me not to worry about it and just keep my head held high.  I felt good getting day 1 over with, but had the comfort of an office to hide in.  There are only about 5 people upstairs with me, while the operations (40) are all downstairs.  I was so mad this morning that I had to go to work bald, I was considering going on disability right then & there!  I just kept telling myself that I have cancer, I'm going to get through this and everyone knows what I look like with hair and now they know what I will look like without hair.  I kept trying to also remind myself that unfortunately this is part of winning the battle with cancer and I'm going to win this damn battle even if I am bald & boobless!  My husband reminded me that yes, people will look at you for the first day or two when they first see you, then after that, you will be a fixture in the office just like the chairs...blending in.  No one will care after a day or two.  I know he's right, but it's humiliating...completely humiliating and I'm pissed that I have to deal with it! I also think we will get more and more used to being bald as the days go by and we are out in public etc.  I just purchased a couple scarves online as I really don't think the wig thing will work for me.  I just can't get past the thought of it falling off, being cockeyed on my head, slipping etc...that day at work just wrecked it for me.  Now to top it off, my head has broken out with pimples and red spots on it!  When we first shaved it, it looked fine...now it's totally ugly.  I also noticed after looking further in the mirror at the back of my head, I officially have an egg shaped head.  Ok, I am offically done venting...for today that is.  ;) Anyway, just wanted to let you know that your not alone. Big hugs from California.....Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 11:10AM BShoemaker wrote: Well ladies, had an allergic reaction to the last Taxotere infusion...broke out in a very itchy rash/hives all over my body.  I was ready to rip my skin off.  Called the urgent care line & they ordered a prescription to calm it down...glad it worked fairly quickly.  The outcome though is that I had to switch chemo meds.  My Oncologist said I have to go on Epirubison now for the last two treatments before surgery.  I'm freaked by it because of the possible heart issues etc...  I just had my first treatment yesterday.  I'm peeing pink now.  My nurse called it the big guns.  My Onc. said after surgery, I'll do 2 more Chemo infusions called FEC...it will be a lower dosage of the Epirubison and Cytoxan.  The only good news was that my treatment is only 1 hr & 30 minutes now.  Much quicker. Can anyone tell me if they are on this drug and how they've been doing?  My other struggle is whether to go for reconstruction or not.  I'm having a bilateral mastectomy, but am really struggling with this decision.  Part of me feels like I should just focus on getting rid of the cancer and screw getting boobs with all the possible issues that can happen with recon...not to mention numerous surgeries for another 6-9 months because my only option is DIEP.  Anyone really happy without doing recon? Thanks for any insight...Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 03:16PM BShoemaker wrote: Just-Mary - I was advised to take Zantac before & after chemo day for heart burn.  Were you given that same info?  Check with you chemo nurses or oncologist. I have a story for you gals.  I have been holding off like a moron from shaving my head and had very thick hair so it's taken a while for it to finally be at a place where I had to get rid of it.  Anyway, hubby shaved it for me last night.  I was shocked in that I didn't shed a tear.  We laughed and made jokes about it and I was really okay with it.  However, this morning I was VERY uncomfortable going to work with my new wig on.  The color is a bit dark and the style is cute, but I felt like everyone in the world would be able to tell.  Anyway, I get to work and try to hide in my office.  Then a co-worker advised he needed help downstairs on his computer so I went to help him.  Two male employees walked past me and commented that my hair looked nice...ok...so far, so good.  I'm sitting working on the computer with him and one of the girls at my office walks up behind me and runs her hand through my hair to exclaim how cute my new haircut looked!  I thought I was going to KILL HER!  Only a couple people at work know about my cancer etc, so I don't think she had any idea I had a wig on.  The wig tilted a bit...enough I think for them to notice.  I could have just died right there.  I told her don't touch my hair and she asked me to step outside for a minute, then I informed her she had just ran her fingers through my WIG and I have cancer.  She looked completely shocked.  She apologized and started asking me questions and I answered a couple (what kind of cancer, are you going through Chemo etc...) then she stated she was going to have to go back to her desk so she didn't start crying.  Well good for her, I'm going to the bathroom to fix my damn wig!  I mean really...who touches your hair at work???  I barely know this girl???  I could have beat her with a baseball bat right then & there!  My first day to wear it and this is what happens?  You must be kidding me!   No one has ever touched my hair before...then on the day I wear a wig you run your hand through it????  WTF??? I have decided I don't think I can do the wig thing at work.  I am so worried about it all day long feeling as though it's going to slide off etc...  I think I'm going to just keep it for emergencies, but will wear a hat or scarf to work.  Screw this wig business!  By the way.  My head is so tender and is bugging me.  My head feel like I have a bunch of pins or needles in it.  Ok, I'm done venting now.  I feel better.  I might even be able to laugh about the wig incident later...  Tomorrow is Chemo #2.  Hoping everyone is doing well.  Hang in there ladies...maybe at least I provided you with a laugh about my wig today!!! Hugs, Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 10:10PM BShoemaker wrote: TomnDi - Hi Tom...glad you enjoyed the story and I was able to provide a little educational info as well!  ha ha ha...   Tom, your wife is SO VERY LUCKY to have you at her side during this time in her life.  Seriously, you sound like an amazing husband to get on these boards,research & share with us your story.  You should be very proud of yourself...you really should. Tom, you said Diane is insistent on going to work even though her doc recommended she does not.  Remind her that her work will be there when she returns.  Her health is the most important thing right now and she needs to take great care of herself.  Is it possible for her to work from home via computer/phone or maybe at least only work half days?  See if she will compromise at least. Best of luck...hang in there, Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 10:30PM BShoemaker wrote: Hello Ladies, I am packing my "Chemo Bag" for tomorrow morning.  I had my Picc Line put in yesterday and was so worked up that I made myself miserable over it.  It was interesting to see how the procedure works.  The Picc Line is bugging me a little, my arm is very sore, but I think it may be worth not getting pricked a million times.  I'm sick of needles already and I haven't begun any treatment at all yet...just test after test.  Anyway, good luck to everyone.  I will be sure and post my results of Chemo as soon as possible.  By the way, I still have not been able to get out to buy hats, wigs etc...I just can't seem to bring myself to do it.  I don't want to! Hugs to you all...Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 05:10PM BShoemaker wrote: Tom, I started to lose my hair on day 15, however, I had very thick, slightly long hair so I was able to hang on to it for another 4-5 days as it continued to fall out. Not sure how thick Diane's hair is, but it certainly helped me!  (Although it made quite the mess!) I was glad when I finally shaved it because I had had enough of cleaning up the hair, picking it off my clothes and brushing out clumps.  I think it just made things worse in the long run. Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 09:33AM BShoemaker wrote: TomnDi: As far as your wife's first treatment, I would strongly suggest you go with her for the first one just in case.  Usually there are no issues, but sometimes people have a bad reaction to one of the drugs. It was a great comfort to have my husband & dad with me. Plus it makes the time go by faster.  We planned for my treatments to be on a Thursday because by Sat, the nausea sets in.  It might work well for you too if you have weekends off to be with her at home.   Make sure she eats a good breakfast...my doc suggested a poached egg & toast.  Bring lots of liquid...my orders were to drink 64 ounces of gatorade.  Water is good too.  Her doctor should have given her instructions on how to prepare for her specific treatment so I don't want you to use my info...just get instructions from the doctor or nurse in charge of her treatment.  As you can see everyone reacts differently, but I think many of us feel fine the day of Chemo & the day after...then the light nausea kicks in on day 3 & 4.  I felt a bit of nausea and dizzyness if I stood for too long.  Had to take a quick shower & sit back down again.  They have great meds for nausea these days so she'll probably be just fine. Best of luck to you both! Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 11:30PM BShoemaker wrote: Hello ladies, well it's day 15 for me from my 1st chemo treatment and my hair is falling out like mad!  My wig arrived in the mail, but we missed the delivery!  I'm picking it up first thing tomorrow morning at the post office.  This seems so WEIRD!  Anyway, I hope it looks and feels ok.  If all goes well, I may shave my head on Sunday.    It's so strange because like many of you had mentioned my scalp/head does feel sore.  What a strange sensation! My next Chemo is Thursday of next week.  For those of you that hate getting pricked with needles, I have been VERY happy with my picc line.  Yes, you have to wrap it up for protection when you shower, but I don't care!  It beats getting pricked over and over again.  They can use it to draw blood as well.  There is no needle prick at all as many of you have mentioned in regards to the Port.  Anyway, it's another option to discuss with your Oncologist. Cherneski, in regards to sleep, I have been taking Tylenol PM and it works like a charm for me. Hope everyone is hanging in there! Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 07:34AM BShoemaker wrote: My Chemo teacher recommended I drink gatorade during the Chemo infusion.  I drank 64 oz's during my infusion and I would guess it helped a lot.  Made many trips to the ladies room, but I think it really helped. I had some flushing in my face & chest, but it really didn't bother me...i just looked like I had a light sunburn.  I just kept drinking gatorade & water during the next few days after treatment.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 05:46PM BShoemaker wrote: Oh Jo, I am so, so sorry to hear that!  My nurse explained some other patients of hers that had bad reactions to the Taxatere as well.  Shoot!  She said they had to give them different cocktails because of it.  Geez, that really sucks...it's bad enough we have to through this crap, then to have a bad reaction to the Chemo really tops it off.  Hang in there...hopefully they will adjust your "cocktail" to be more suitable to your body.  Hang in there sweetie...keep us posted!  I'm rooting for you! Hugs, Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 06:43PM BShoemaker wrote: Hello ladies..Bettina here...I am doing pretty darn good today...day 2 after my first Chemo appt.  My only issues today are that my face & chest are flushed red.  Other than that, I'm doing great and no sign of nausea.  I have been taking Compazine just in case though every six hours or so.  I have been eating small, light meals and drinking gatorade.  I was also told there may be a burning sensation when you urinate after getting the Taxotere.  I have not had that issue at all.  I feel sleepy, but my doctors office called to check on me and advised the Compazine is probably making me sleepy.  It's weird because I was expecting all these issues and just waiting for something to happen, but I'm really doing well.  I'm so thankful!  I had no problem sleeping last night.  I crashed out!  I was told it was okay to take Tylenol PM though if I needed it.  Just ask your doctor what's okay for you to take for sleep issues. Best of luck to you all! Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:34PM BShoemaker wrote: Day 4 after Chemo and I finally felt sick Saturday afternoon and Sunday.  Not terribly sick, but dizzy at times where you have to sit down and slightly sick to my stomach.  I knew things were going too well!  I know it could be way worse, so I won't complain too much.  I dragged myself to try on wigs today because I know I'm running out of time.  I thought I looked like a MUPPET!  I tried on some hats, but have never looked good in hats so that was a wash too.  Uggg!!  It's bad enough they are taking my boobs...do they have to take my hair too???  Damn!  Okay, enough of the self pitty party.  To those of you that are not sleeping, check with your doctor if you can take Tylenol PM.  It works like a charm for me!  I get a full nights sleep. Bettina
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Now if I can just will my hair to stay...all will be good with the world!  LOL! Hugs, Bettina

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 02:27AM BShoemaker wrote: ddlatt, thanks for the info!  Appreciate it.  You always have interesting posts...I was very interested in your case because if I recall correctly you didn't get reconstructive surgery...I am considering going the same route myself.  I haven't met with my surgeon yet, (June 8) but am struggling with this.  Not to mention the hat & wig shopping...uggg... Bluedasher, today was my first day and I did really well.  No bad reactions and loved my nurse.  I have a Picc Line...THANK GOODNESS!  I love it!  I hate needles so this is such a relief to me and my nurse...she was thrilled too!  I am taking Benedryl, Decadron & Zantac before the Chemo.  I was very alert during the Chemo, but also had my dad, stepmom & hubby with me.  We chatted the entire time and I met a really sweet lady next to me that had Ovarian cancer about 5 years ago and no recurrence, but now has Lymphoma.  She had a great attitude and was full of good advice.  The only mistake I made was not wearing a short sleeve shirt because of the Picc Line...next time I will!  I just wanted to be warm is all.  I will take your advise on the ice chips for next time.  They also provided blankets, pillows, hard candy, crackers etc...  I brought my gatorade. Thanks Lisa as always...great advice!  I think the pad of paper/pen is a great idea as I think of questions...we had quite a few today! Hugs, bettina
Posts.Title: What do you pack for Chemo? BShoemaker Moderators

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 08:40PM BShoemaker wrote: I also wore my own clothes, but found out if you have a Picc Line or Port, make sure to wear clothing so that they can access it easily.  Maybe a V-neck shirt or short sleeve shirt for the Picc Line.  My place provided hard candy, crackers & water if you needed it.  I just brought my own stash of gatorade & hard candy.  I ate breakfast before I left the house. Best of luck! Bettina
Posts.Title: What do you pack for Chemo? BShoemaker Moderators

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 09:37PM BShoemaker wrote: Deanna, Thanks for the tip on the ice.  Yes, I am getting Taxotere.  I am bringing my Gatorade on ice packs in a small cooler bag so maybe I could use those during the Taxotere drip.  So do you suggest just resting my finger tips & toes on the ice packs then?? Thanks, Bettina
